tweets.text:
@negativeyieId @BoringBiz_ Like all unproductive commodities, Pokemon card prices all comes down to whether the future playerbase is bigger / spends more than current player base. 

Card producers need a way to carefully manage this "token economy" to sell their inventory while still not devaluing it.

profile_bio.description:
Software engineer. ex-quant.

All relevant links on the website.

tweets.text:
Central banks is like the One Ring in Tolkien's fantasy. 

Everyone succumbs to it, regardless of them being a hero in their early life. 

And it always drives civilization towards tyranny. Ring changes hands, and we get a full circle.

profile_bio.description:
Software engineer. ex-quant.

All relevant links on the website.

tweets.text:
@BoringBiz_ You assume a "carry risk" people don't talk about. 

The returns you get is based on the risk that: 
- cards get damaged
- future demand increases
- future supply is controlled very well by Pokemon Inc
- you can liquidate it at spot at no discount

If its that profitable every store keeper would have hoarded.

value.string_value: High-growth tech companies are very expensive.

tweets.text:
@willdepue Statistics prove the opposite. The better public workers get paid relative to private workers, the worse policies and service gets. 

CA has the highest public-private wage ratio in US. Guess which state has the worst social welfare? 

Argentina has the highest public-private wage ratio in LatAm. Guess which country has some of the highest inflation? 

Every extra dollar that goes to state workers funds their unlimited objective against trade freedom
